text: hey guys after finishing my x-ray
backscatter imaging project I realized
that I could also build an x-ray CT
scanner which produces even more
interesting images so let me show you
what's involved a CT scanner or cat
scanner is they used to be called stands
for computed tomography where tomography
means that we're going to get a
sectional view like a slice through a 3d
object and computed because we're going
to use a an algorithm to reconstruct the
3d image since we can't actually cut
what we want to inspect with a knife to
get a slice of it what we have to do is
take x-ray images from around the
periphery of the object and then use a
computer algorithm to reconstruct all
the 3d data in a conventional medical CT
scanner the patient stays still and the
x-ray source and the x-ray detector
circulate around the patient in a ring
electro mechanically this is fairly
difficult because the rotating ring has
to have an electrical connection that
goes through the rotating surface so
they probably use an RF transmitter or
something to get the data out and then
slip rings to get the power in in my
case since I don't want to build
something that big I'm going to keep the
X ray source and detector still and then
rotate the object the x-ray source that
I'm using is a standard x-ray tube
probably very similar to those used in
commercial CT scanners but mine is
fairly less powerful
so my tube runs at about 50 kilovolts at
about one milliamp so the x-ray beam
will turn on and illuminate the phosphor
screen and the subject in this case a
frozen chicken will obstruct the x-rays
and create a shadow on the screen so
I'll get a picture of that and then the
x-rays will shut off the camera will end
the exposure and I'll rotate the subject
by about eight degrees and then turn on
the x-ray and make another exposure it
can continue doing this all the way
around 300
60 degrees the output of this data
collection is 45 two-dimensional images
that show x-rays penetrating all the way
through the subject unfortunately this
doesn't give us any 3d information
directly all we have is a bunch of 2d
images so we feed this into an algorithm
called filtered back projection which
basically does the reverse of what
happened in reality so imagine in the
computer there is a three-dimensional
space occupying the space where the
subject would be and the two-dimensional
image from the phosphor screen is
extruded along a path heading back to
the x-ray source so we know that all the
shadows created on the screen were
caused by features in the 3d subject and
we know that the only source of x-rays
here is basically a pinpoint a point
source inside the x-ray tube so if we if
we trace all the shadows on that screen
back to the point source inside the
x-ray tube then we'll know where all
those features existed in the 3d volume
and what we do is we add up all of the
images all the 45 images by rotating
this model around 8 degrees at a time
and space we end up with a 3d volume of
data and we can use that to create a 3d
rendering or we can produce a slice at
any angle and position through the
through the volume to take a look at
what's inside the object
I built this project using an Arduino to
sequence the whole thing and the Arduino
controls a stepper motor driver and the
stepper motor is coupled to a very large
ring bearing just through some rubber
o-rings right on the shaft of the
stepper motor and I calibrated this by
spinning the whole thing around by one
full revolution and Counting how many
steps it took and then dividing by 45
originally I was going to stay in the
garage and coordinate all this by hand
but the amount of backscatter x-ray is
coming off of the screen in the shop
walls and everything was kind of more
than I wanted one problem is that the
camera takes 30 seconds to get a good
exposure at ISO 800 and then the camera
automatically does a dark frame
subtraction so each exposure takes
below for a minute and I need 45
exposures so it's kind of a long time to
be hanging around so I set up the
Arduino and used a an intervalometer to
control my camera and then use the
Arduino to control the intervalometer I
could have gone directly from the
Arduino to my camera but I didn't have
the weird 4-conductor tiny phone jack
that goes into the camera body the
Arduino also controls the x-ray tube so
during the camera's dark frame it shuts
the x-ray tube off so that it maintains
about a 50 percent duty cycle which is
you know fine without a fan even for
this x-ray tube my garage is pretty dark
at night so I just added a couple of
very simple light blockers to keep small
light sources from outside the garage
from getting in through the windows and
I was able to do a 30 second exposure
without much background noise at all
processing the images was fairly
straightforward I used Panasonic's
silky picks which came with my camera
and captured the images in raw and then
exported them is 16 bit monochrome
Tiff's to try to get as much dynamic
range as possible and then I used Adobe
bridge and the batch setting in there to
perform it's the same set of actions on
each photo
so in Photoshop I imported one and set
up some guides and distorted the picture
back to square so since I was using my
camera to take a picture of the screen
off axis there's quite a bit of
perspective distortion so I used
Photoshop to correct for that and play
with the levels a little bit until I
ended up with an image as if the camera
were in line one reason not to put the
camera in line of the x-rays is that you
get a lot of hot pixels so if I turn to
the projection screen or the phosphorous
screen around and then put the camera
straight on to it the camera would be in
the x-ray beam and that would definitely
caused quite a bit of pixel noise okay
hope you enjoyed that see you next time
bye
